cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: During the basic control skills test, you can acquire points by:
questions.answerC: Exiting the vehicle one time to check your positioning.
questions.explanation: The examiner will score the number of times your vehicle touches or crosses an exercise boundary line. Each encroachment will count as an error, resulting in points against your skills test score.

questions.question: During exercises that are not the straight line backing exercise, you may exit your vehicle to check its position no more than:
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: When preparing to enter traffic, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Wait for a large gap between vehicles.
questions.answerB: Be prepared for your vehicle to accelerate slowly, especially if it is loaded.
questions.answerC: Make sure you can completely cross traffic, if necessary, without interfering with traffic.
questions.answerD: Assume other drivers will make room for your much larger vehicle.
questions.explanation: When crossing or entering traffic, bear in mind the size of your vehicle and the distance it will need to accelerate. Wait for a gap in traffic that is large enough to accommodate your vehicle before you begin to accelerate. Remember that you will need more room to accelerate if your vehicle is heavily loaded. Before crossing a road, be sure that you can get all the way across without interfering with traffic.

questions.question: You can be denied a hazardous materials endorsement for:
questions.answerA: Being a permanent resident of the United States.
questions.answerB: Never having been convicted of a felony.
questions.answerC: Have been committed to a mental institution.
questions.explanation: You will be denied a HazMat endorsement, or lose an existing endorsement, if you are not a lawful permanent U.S. resident; you renounce your U.S. citizenship; you are wanted for, under indictment for, or convicted of certain felonies; you are judged as mentally unstable or are committed to a mental institution; or you are deemed to pose a security threat by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: When other vehicles have trouble seeing you at dawn or dusk, you can increase your visibility by:
questions.explanation: At dawn or dusk, and in snowy or rainy conditions, you should turn on your headlights to make it easier for other road users to see your vehicle.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without a moving violation.
questions.answerD: Obey all traffic signs and signals, but only if other traffic is present.
questions.explanation: You must drive in a safe and responsible manner during the on-road driving test. This includes wearing your safety belt; obeying all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and completing the test without an accident or moving violation.

questions.question: Hydraulic brakes can fail due to:
questions.answerC: Driving uphill for long periods of time.
questions.explanation: Failure of hydraulic brakes is often caused by a loss of hydraulic pressure. Hydraulic brakes may also fade because of overuse on a long downgrade.

questions.question: A vehicle stopped at a green light may indicate that the driver:
questions.answerC: Does not know the rules of the road.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they stop in inappropriate places, such as at green traffic lights.

questions.question: Brakes may get out of adjustment:
questions.explanation: Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially if they are used to the point of overheating. Brake adjustment should be checked frequently.

questions.question: What kind of force must emergency brakes use?
questions.explanation: Because air pressure can eventually leak away, the emergency brakes in an air brake system must be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you are carrying a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: When drivers turn, they usually:
questions.answerA: Look in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Look in the direction opposite the turn.
questions.explanation: When turning, drivers usually look in the direction of their turn. If a driver fails to signal before a turn or lane change, their body movements may still provide a clue that they are planning to turn.

questions.question: If you need to travel down a hill, you should switch into a lower gear:
questions.answerB: As you go downhill and pick up speed.
questions.answerD: Near the bottom of the hill.
questions.explanation: Always downshift before beginning to drive downhill. Forcing an automatic transmission into a lower gear at a high speed could damage the transmission and also lead to a loss of ability to engine brake. Drive at a speed that will allow you to control your vehicle without overusing your brakes. When determining a safe speed to drive, you should take into account the steepness of the grade, the length of the grade, the weight of your vehicle, road conditions, and weather conditions.

questions.question: To make driving at night easier, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your interior light turned on.
questions.answerB: Adjust the instrument panel lights as dimly as you can while still being able to read the gauges.
questions.answerC: Not take a nap before driving.
questions.answerD: Use only your low beam headlights.
questions.explanation: If the interior of your cab is too bright when you are driving at night, you may have difficulty seeing things outside. Keep the interior light off and adjust your instrument lights to the lowest possible level that still allows you to easily read the gauges.

questions.question: If a truck's Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working:
questions.answerA: The truck will not have any brakes.
questions.answerB: The truck should be driven only at slow speeds.
questions.answerC: The truck will still have brakes.
questions.answerD: The truck will lack brakes on its left side.
questions.explanation: If an ABS system fails, the vehicle will still have normal braking function. The driver should continue to drive and brake as they normally would.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using flashing lights so other road users move out of your path.
questions.answerC: Drive at a safe speed and arrive when you arrive.
questions.explanation: To avoid engaging in dangerous and aggressive driving behavior, you should relax and accept any delays that arise throughout a trip. To help avoid the stress of arriving late to a destination, plan for likely delays when planning your drive.

questions.question: On a leaf spring, the leaves:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's suspension, you should look for broken or missing leaves in the leaf springs. Any defect of this kind is dangerous. If one-fourth or more of the leaves are missing from any leaf spring, the vehicle must be put out-of-service.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a driver who might be a hazard?
questions.answerA: A driver operating a vehicle without first scraping ice off the windshield
questions.answerB: The operator of a rental truck
questions.answerC: The driver of a station wagon with items covering the back windows
questions.answerD: A person operating a pick-up truck
questions.explanation: Drivers with blocked vision may pose hazards to others on the road. Examples of such drivers include those who haven't scraped ice off of their windshields; those driving vehicles loaded with large items blocking the windows; and those who are driving rental trucks without being used to the limited rear visibility of a truck.

questions.question: Blocking a load:
questions.answerA: Is dangerous and should never be done.
questions.answerD: Can only be done in dry weather.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be blocked to prevent it from sliding around in transit. The shifting of weight in transit can make steering and handling difficult for the driver.

questions.question: If a tire fails, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Keep one hand on the steering wheel and use their other hand to wave to other drivers.
questions.explanation: If a tire fails, braking could cause a loss of control. Unless braking is necessary to avoid a hazard, you should stay off the brakes until your vehicle has slowed considerably. Only then should you brake very gently, pull off the road, and stop.

questions.question: Vehicles with dual air brake systems:
questions.answerA: Maintain full-capacity air pressure in the braking systems even when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerB: Maintain some air pressure in the braking systems when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerC: Must be run to build enough air pressure to brakes to operate properly.
questions.answerD: Do not need time to build air pressure before a trip.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must allow the air compressor time to build up at least 100 psi of air pressure in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: Fuel records supporting IFTA quarterly fuel use tax returns must be kept by carriers for:
questions.explanation: In general, if you operate a commercial vehicle in interstate commerce, it must be registered under the International Registration Plan (IRP) and International Fuel Tax Agreement (IFTA). These programs collect and distribute vehicle registration fees and fuel taxes based on what jurisdictions you drive in and for how long. Mileage and fuel records supporting IFTA quarterly fuel tax returns must be retained by carriers for four years.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are activated, you should never:
questions.answerC: Release air from the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Open the door to the cab.
questions.explanation: Never apply the brake pedal if your spring breaks are activated. Brakes can be damaged if they are subject to both springs and air pressure.

questions.question: If feeling sleepy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster to arrive to your destination sooner.
questions.answerC: Leave the road and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel sleepy while driving, the only safe response is to stop driving and get some sleep. Attempting to fight off exhaustion is dangerous and a major cause of fatal crashes. Stimulants are not a safe solution because they may help keep you awake but will not make you more alert. Once stimulants wear off, you will be even more tired than you were originally.

questions.question: After the engine is started, warning lights and buzzers should all:
questions.answerD: Turn off once the vehicle begins moving.
questions.explanation: After the engine is started, the warning lights and buzzers should deactivate immediately. The charging circuit warning, oil, coolant, and Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) lights should all turn off.

questions.question: A stopped bus:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern.
questions.answerB: Is not a concern if passengers are not unloading.
questions.answerC: Should not be on the roadway.
questions.answerD: Is a concern, whether passengers are visible or not.
questions.explanation: Always drive cautiously around a stopped bus. Passengers may cross in front of or behind it, and the bus may prevent them from seeing your vehicle.

questions.question: When driving, the steering wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Held with both hands on opposite sides of the wheel.
questions.answerC: Held with both hands at the bottom of the wheel.
questions.answerD: Held with both hands at the top of the wheel.
questions.explanation: Hold the steering wheel firmly with both hands, placing them on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: When driving:
questions.answerA: It is best to hide your intentions from others.
questions.answerB: You should only use turn signals if there are vehicles near you.
questions.answerC: You should not use turn signals in construction zones.
questions.answerD: You should always use turn signals to warn others about your intentions.
questions.explanation: It is important to communicate your intentions to others on the road. Make sure to signal before turning or changing lanes, even if no other vehicles are nearby.

questions.question: If a tire rim is damaged, it should be:
questions.answerD: Put on the axle farthest from the driver.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims with welding repairs are not safe.

questions.question: During the steering box portion of the vehicle inspection test, you should not:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the steering box is securely mounted.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the steering box is free of leaks.
questions.answerC: Look for missing bolts in the steering box.
questions.answerD: Assume all cotter keys are present.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that the steering box is securely mounted. Check for missing nuts, bolts, and cotter keys. Be sure that there are no power steering fluid leaks and that there is no damage to power steering hoses.

questions.question: A driver will lose their CDL for at least one year for:
questions.answerA: Leaving the scene of an accident involving a CMV.
questions.explanation: Leaving the scene of an accident involving a CMV will result in loss of your CDL for at least one year.

questions.question: When checking the springs during a vehicle inspection, do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Ensure torsion springs are not damaged.
questions.explanation: When checking the springs as part of the vehicle inspection test, you should look for missing, shifted, cracked, or broken leaf springs, as well as broken or distorted coil springs. If the vehicle is equipped with torsion bars, torque arms, or other types of suspension components, ensure that they are not damaged and are mounted securely.

questions.question: It is illegal to operate a CMV with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.explanation: It is illegal to operate a CMV with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.04 percent or higher. Operating a CMV while under the influence of alcohol will result in loss of license for at least one year.

questions.question: Distracted drivers may be:
questions.answerC: Preoccupied with using their cell phones.
questions.answerD: Not talking to anyone else in their vehicles.
questions.explanation: You may be able to tell that another driver is distracted if you can see them drifting within a lane or across lane dividers; traveling at inconsistent speeds; being preoccupied with a cell phone, a map, food, or other items; or engaging in conversation with passengers.

questions.question: You should always use at least ____ to secure cargo on a flatbed trailer.
questions.explanation: When transporting cargo on a flatbed trailer, you should use at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Any cargo, no matter how small, should be restrained by a minimum of two tie-downs.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving skills test, you will be evaluated on your gear usage. You should not:
questions.answerB: Select a gear that does not rev the engine.
questions.answerC: Forget to shift through an intersection.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you will be evaluated on your gear usage. Select a gear that does not rev or lug the engine; avoid grinding and clashing gears; and avoid shifting through turns or intersections.

questions.question: When backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly to get out of the way of other drivers.
questions.answerB: Try not to use your mirrors.
questions.explanation: Backing a large CMV is always dangerous because you will not be able to see everything behind you. If you must back up, use a helper, if possible.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road to spot potential hazards in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards if they become dangerous.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Has a single air brake system, but uses two sets of controls.
questions.answerB: Has one air brake system for each side of the truck.
questions.answerC: Has two brakes for each wheel.
questions.answerD: Has two separate air brake systems, but uses a single set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems that use a single set of brake controls. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles. The other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: Most heavy vehicles require ____ to change gears.
questions.explanation: Most heavy vehicles with manual transmissions require double clutching to change gears. A driver should release the accelerator, push in the clutch, and shift into neutral at the same time. After releasing the clutch and allowing the vehicle to change to the necessary speed, the driver should push in the clutch, shift gears, then simultaneously release the clutch and accelerate.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerA: Stop harder than you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerC: Brake as you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.answerD: Brake with less force than you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination that is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would if the vehicle was not equipped with ABS.

questions.question: While driving, if it is discovered a vehicle's ABS is not working, the driver should:
questions.answerD: Use their parking brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working, the vehicle's basic braking functions are still intact. The driver should continue to drive and brake in a normal fashion.

questions.question: The suspension system:
questions.answerA: Holds up the vehicle and its load.
questions.answerB: Keeps the load the proper distance behind the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Maintains a safe distance between the vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Lightens the load for the tires.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Damage to a suspension system can be very dangerous.

questions.question: Headlights:
questions.answerA: Are not usually necessary when driving at night.
questions.answerB: Provide better light than the sun.
questions.answerC: Should be on the high beam setting whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Should always be on the high beam setting.
questions.explanation: To improve visibility, you should use high beam headlights at night where it is safe and legal to do so. However, the glare from high beam lights can blind other drivers. You should dim your lights to their low beam setting when driving within 500 feet of an approaching vehicle.

questions.question: What is a wig wag?
questions.answerB: A tube used to move air from the compressor to the tanks
questions.answerC: A noise made by air brakes when used
questions.answerD: A part within the braking unit that allows air to move freely
questions.explanation: A wig wag is a type of low air pressure warning device in an air brake system. It drops a mechanical arm into the driver's view when the air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi.

questions.question: Eating while driving:
questions.answerA: Is a good way to maximize time.
questions.answerC: Creates a distraction for the driver.
questions.answerD: Is mandatory so cargo is not left unsupervised.
questions.explanation: To reduce the chances of driving distracted, you should avoid eating, drinking, or smoking while driving. Anything that diverts attention from the task of driving is a distraction.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driver’s side.
questions.answerD: Only use the mirror on the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: To remain aware of hazards behind your vehicle when backing, you should frequently check your mirrors on both sides of the vehicle. Have a helper watch your blind spots whenever possible.

questions.question: If you experience a loss of hydraulic pressure, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you experience a loss of hydraulic pressure in your brakes, you should downshift, pump the brakes, and use the parking brake. Seek an escape route, such as an escape ramp, open field, or side street.

questions.question: When asked to make a turn while taking your driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signal, but only if other cars are present.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.answerC: Inspected only if they seem frayed.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, belts in the engine compartment should be checked for tightness and excessive wear.

questions.question: When checking its automatic transmission fluid, the vehicle:
questions.answerA: Should be placed on an incline.
questions.answerB: Should be placed on a decline.
questions.answerD: Should be lifted with a jack.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's engine may need to be running in order for you to check the level of its automatic transmission fluid.

questions.question: If driving a truck that requires a CDL for operation:
questions.answerA: You do not need to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if transporting more than 500 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerC: You are always required to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerD: You are only required to wear a seat belt when driving a tank trailer.
questions.explanation: For safety, you must wear your seat belt at all times while operating a CMV.

questions.question: Header boards:
questions.answerB: Protect the driver from being hit by cargo.
questions.answerC: Protect the driver's head when entering the cab of a truck.
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you are carrying a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: In a newer vehicle, you apply the parking brake:
questions.answerA: By using a diamond-shaped yellow knob.
questions.answerB: By using a round red knob.
questions.answerC: By using a square green knob.
questions.answerD: By using a black round knob.
questions.explanation: In a newer vehicle with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the parking brakes and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: If federal inspectors judge your vehicle to be unsafe, they can:
questions.answerA: Bring you to a garage to have your vehicle fixed.
questions.answerB: Formerly request that you have your vehicle's problems fixed.
questions.answerD: Pull the vehicle out-of-service until it is fixed.
questions.explanation: If a federal or state inspector judges a CMV to be unsafe, they may put it out-of-service until it is fixed.

questions.question: If driving a school bus, your four-way flashers should:
questions.answerA: Be activated before crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Only be used after crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerD: Only be used near railroad tracks if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: When driving a school bus, you must activate your four-way flashers while approaching and crossing a railroad crossing. Deactivate the flashers once your entire vehicle has cleared the tracks.

questions.question: If equipped, a header board should:
questions.answerC: Be strong enough to contain cargo.
questions.answerD: Light up when the engine is started.
questions.explanation: When checking a header board during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that it is secure, free of damage, and strong enough to contain cargo.

questions.question: If an approaching driver is using their high beam headlights, you should:
questions.answerB: Flash your high beam lights to remind the driver to switch to their low beams.
questions.answerC: Look to the right side of your lane until the vehicle has passed.
questions.answerD: Pull to the side of the road until the vehicle has passed.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is coming toward you while using its high beam headlights, glance away from the headlights and toward the right side of the road until the vehicle has passed. This will keep you from being blinded by the lights.

questions.question: What is a Gross Vehicle Weight Rating?
questions.answerA: The maximum weight stated by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle
questions.answerB: The maximum weight that can be pulled by a single vehicle
questions.answerC: The minimum weight that can be hauled by a single vehicle
questions.answerD: The maximum amount that can be loaded onto a single trailer
questions.explanation: Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the weight specified by the manufacturer as the maximum weight of a single vehicle and its load.

questions.question: Which of the following is not acceptable emergency equipment?
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will need to show emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and a properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: After starting the engine, oil pressure should reach a normal level:
questions.explanation: After you start the engine, keep an eye on the gauges. Oil pressure should rise to a normal level within a few seconds of the engine being started.

questions.question: Front brake limiting valves were intended to:
questions.answerA: Prevent the front tires from skidding.
questions.answerB: Prevent the front tires from overheating.
questions.answerD: Remove uncertainty when applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Some older vehicles with air brakes have front brake limiting valves. These valves were intended to reduce the risk of front wheels skidding. However, research has shown that such devices are unnecessary, so they should be left in the "normal" position.

questions.question: Alcohol can be removed from your system:
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate, so the only way to sober up after consuming alcohol is to allow your body time to remove the alcohol on its own.

questions.question: Eating while driving is:
questions.answerA: A good way to save time.
questions.answerC: Acceptable if you are eating foods that are easy to eat.
questions.explanation: Smoking, eating, or drinking are distracting activities and should be avoided while you are driving. Instead, plan ahead and allow yourself time to stop to eat when making a lengthy trip.

questions.question: When alley docking, your vehicle should be parked:
questions.answerA: With the front bumper on top of the front boundary line.
questions.answerB: With the rear wheels over the rear boundary line.
questions.answerC: Straight within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.answerD: At an angle within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: When turning quickly to avoid an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply your brakes as you steer.
questions.answerB: Give yourself extra clearance by turning more than needed to miss the object.
questions.answerC: Turn just enough to miss the object and avoid turning more.
questions.answerD: Steer and accelerate at the same time.
questions.explanation: When turning quickly to avoid an object, turn only as much as is necessary to clear it. Do not apply the brakes while turning.

questions.question: Maintaining a cushion of space between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead is:
questions.answerA: Not encouraged, as it slows the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: Encouraged, as it allows you time to react to unexpected hazards.
questions.answerC: Only encouraged if you are traveling with a passenger.
questions.explanation: For safe driving, it is essential that you maintain cushions of space on all sides of your vehicle. This helps to ensure that you will have time to take appropriate action if a problem arises.

questions.question: A modulating control valve can control the:
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: If you are turning left and there are two available left turn lanes, which lane should you choose?
questions.answerD: Trucks should not turn where there are two left turn lanes.
questions.explanation: A large vehicle may need to swing right to make a left turn. If an intersection has two left turn lanes, the driver should choose the righthand land to begin their turn.

questions.question: While driving, if it is discovered a vehicle's ABS is not working, the driver should:
questions.answerD: Use their parking brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working, the vehicle's basic braking functions are still intact. The driver should continue to drive and brake in a normal fashion.

questions.question: When starting the engine as part of the pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.explanation: Check your engine during the pre-trip inspection. After starting the engine, you should listen for unusual noises.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A double combination vehicle should have a leakage rate no higher than 4 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: While driving, if you notice anything affecting safety or mechanics, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay quiet and see if the problem goes away.
questions.answerB: Make a written report that includes your concerns.
questions.answerC: Try to fix the issue yourself.
questions.answerD: Not use that part of the vehicle and hope others don't notice the problem.
questions.explanation: At the end of each day of driving, you may be required to make a written report on the vehicle or vehicles driven. Be sure to make note of any issues that could affect the safety of the vehicle or that could lead to a mechanical breakdown.

questions.question: It is illegal to operate a CMV with a minimum blood alcohol content (BAC) of:
questions.explanation: Operating a CMV with a minimum blood alcohol content (BAC) of 0.04 percent is illegal and will result in loss of license for at least one year for a first offense. If you operate a CMV with any detectable amount of alcohol in your system while remaining below the legal limit of 0.04 percent, you will be put out-of-service for at least 24 hours.

questions.question: The maximum amount of play that is safe on a 20-inch steering wheel is:
questions.explanation: A steering wheel with play of more than 10 degrees may be defective. On a 20-inch wheel, this is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of the wheel.

questions.question: You should always use at least ____ to secure cargo on a flatbed trailer.
questions.explanation: When transporting cargo on a flatbed trailer, you should use at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Any cargo, no matter how small, should be restrained by a minimum of two tie-downs.

questions.question: During the straight line backing exercise, how many times are you permitted to exit the vehicle to check its position?
questions.explanation: During the straight line backing exercise, you are permitted to exit your vehicle to check its position no more than one time.

questions.question: What is the best way to stop if your brakes fail while you are driving downhill?
questions.answerB: Let the vehicle slow down on its own.
questions.answerC: Let rumble strips slow your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, you will need to quickly find something outside that can stop your vehicle. An escape ramp is the best option. If no escape ramp is available, use the least hazardous available option, such as driving into an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: While driving downhill, you should brake until you reach a speed that is ____ below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: While driving downhill, you should hold down the brake pedal until your vehicle reaches a speed 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal. Repeat this process.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerD: Keep the control at the halfway mark.
questions.explanation: Some pre-1975 vehicles have a front brake limiting valve, which has "normal" and "slippery" settings. The idea behind these valves was to limit the air pressure available to the front brakes when driving on slippery surfaces, and thereby reduce the danger of a front-wheel skid. Studies have found that this is not actually a concern, so if your vehicle has a front brake limiting valve, leave it in the "normal" position.

questions.question: When entering a foggy area, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop on the side of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Always slow down before entering a foggy area. Use low beam headlights, avoid passing others, and avoid stopping on the side of the roadway. It is safest to completely avoid driving under foggy conditions, if possible.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Keep the driver’s side door open.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, it is important that you turn on your emergency flashers as a warning to other drivers. This is especially important if you are stopped at night.

questions.question: To receive a hazardous materials endorsement, an applicant will be required to supply:
questions.answerC: A list of countries visited within the last 10 years.
questions.answerD: Their employment history for the previous five years.
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you will be required to submit your fingerprints and undergo a TSA background check.

questions.question: When asked to make a lane change during the driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Make the change as soon as the examiner asks, without looking.
questions.answerB: Use your turn signal and change lanes when safe.
questions.answerC: Make the lane change as quickly as possible, even if that means cutting off another driver.
questions.explanation: You will be asked to change lanes during the on-road driving test. When the examiner asks you to do this, you should make the necessary traffic checks and use the proper signals before changing lanes.

questions.question: Why do you need to drain air tanks regularly?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water which must be drained from the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in air pressure
questions.answerD: To remove bad air from the tanks
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Overloading a vehicle with cargo:
questions.answerA: Usually has no effect on the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Can impact the vehicle's steering and brake control.
questions.answerC: Can impact the vehicle's electrical system.
questions.explanation: Overloading a vehicle can have negative effects on steering, braking, and speed control. Learn to recognize when cargo is overloaded or poorly balanced.

questions.question: Areas of the road that are shaded:
questions.answerB: Usually do not contain moisture, so they can’t freeze.
questions.answerC: Will remain slick after ice on other areas of the road has melted.
questions.explanation: Because they are exposed to less sunlight, shaded patches of road will stay cooler longer than other areas of the road. Due to the lack of direct sunlight, shady areas can remain icy and slippery after ice on other areas of the road has melted.

questions.question: While operating a CMV:
questions.answerA: You are not required to wear a safety belt.
questions.answerB: You are only required to wear a safety belt if your vehicle does not have airbags.
questions.answerC: You are required to wear a safety belt, but only if hauling more than 1,000 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerD: You are always required to wear a safety belt.
questions.explanation: A safety belt is your best defense in the event of a collision. You must always wear a safety belt while operating a CMV.

questions.question: Driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Safer than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Just as safe as driving during the day.
questions.answerC: More dangerous than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued and impaired drivers on the road.

questions.question: An item that is 40 feet long placed on a flatbed trailer should be secured by at least ____ tie-down(s).
questions.explanation: Cargo on a flatbed trailer should be secured by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of the cargo's length. Cargo should be secured by a minimum of two tie-downs, regardless of size.

questions.question: Texting while driving a CMV is:
questions.answerA: Acceptable if the text is work-related.
questions.answerB: Acceptable if there are fewer than 10 words in the text message.
questions.answerC: Encouraged because it is safer than talking on the phone.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving a commercial motor vehicle is both illegal and dangerous. Manually entering text into or reading text from any electronic device is considered texting.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Develop your own route to show off your driving skills.
questions.answerB: Listen to directions from the examiner.
questions.answerC: Bring a passenger to ride with you.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must listen to and follow the directions given by the examiner. They will never ask you to drive in an unsafe manner.

questions.question: Driving in extremely hot weather:
questions.answerB: Requires you to remove oil from the engine.
questions.explanation: In extremely hot weather, tire pressure can increase to dangerous levels due to the expansion of the air in heat. To keep an engine from overheating, it is important that there be enough oil and coolant in the engine compartment.

questions.question: When checking the engine compartment:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should not be engaged.
questions.answerD: The gearshift should be in first gear.
questions.explanation: Before inspecting the engine compartment, make sure that the parking brakes are on and/or the wheels are chocked. Check the engine compartment before entering the cab and starting the engine.

questions.question: When an engine is started:
questions.answerA: The brakes should be locked up.
questions.answerB: Warning lights should come on and then quickly turn off.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: If you have more than one license:
questions.answerA: You are unlikely to be caught.
questions.answerD: There is no way for authorities to find out.
questions.explanation: A person may not have more than one license. Violation of this law may be punishable by jail time and/or a fine of up to $5,000.

questions.question: Bridges usually:
questions.answerA: Freeze, but only once the temperature drops significantly below 32 degrees Fahrenheit.
questions.answerB: Freeze after other road surfaces freeze.
questions.answerD: Have heaters to prevent them from freezing.
questions.explanation: Bridges usually freeze before the rest of the road. You should be especially careful when crossing bridges if the temperature is near the freezing point.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road to spot potential hazards in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards if they become dangerous.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: On a leaf spring, the leaves:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's suspension, you should look for broken or missing leaves in the leaf springs. Any defect of this kind is dangerous. If one-fourth or more of the leaves are missing from any leaf spring, the vehicle must be put out-of-service.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When it is difficult for others to see your vehicle, such as at dawn or dusk, you can help other drivers by:
questions.answerD: Waving an arm out the window.
questions.explanation: At times when visibility is low, you should turn your headlights on to the low beam setting. If you are having a difficult time seeing others, they are probably having a difficult time seeing you.

questions.question: Eating while driving is:
questions.answerA: A good way to save time.
questions.answerC: Acceptable if you are eating foods that are easy to eat.
questions.explanation: Smoking, eating, or drinking are distracting activities and should be avoided while you are driving. Instead, plan ahead and allow yourself time to stop to eat when making a lengthy trip.

questions.question: If the brakes “pull” to one side or the other when you use them, it's a sign that:
questions.answerB: The brakes need to be checked.
questions.answerD: The brakes have too much stopping power.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle "pulls" to one side when braking, you may have brake trouble. If there is an issue with your brakes, you should fix the issue before driving. Operating an unsafe vehicle is against federal and state laws.

questions.question: When traveling in heavy traffic, the safest driving speed is:
questions.answerC: A speed much slower than the flow of surrounding traffic.
questions.explanation: In heavy traffic, it is safest to match the speed of surrounding vehicles. Vehicles traveling in the same direction at the same speed are unlikely to collide. However, you should not exceed legal speed limits.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is ____ in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Before beginning downhill, you should:
questions.answerB: Take your vehicle out of gear.
questions.answerD: Rely only on braking to reduce your speed.
questions.explanation: On a steep downgrade, you must use the engine's braking effect as your primary method of speed control. Be sure to decelerate and downshift appropriately before beginning to drive down the hill. Relying too heavily on the brakes may cause them to overheat and fade, becoming less effective.

questions.question: Hanging meat as a cargo:
questions.answerD: Creates a low center of gravity.
questions.explanation: Hanging meat can be an unstable load in a vehicle. The truck may become top-heavy and steering may be inhibited by the swinging meat. Drivers carrying such loads should use particular caution when traveling around sharp curves, such as highway entrance and exit ramps.

questions.question: When double clutching, if you remain in neutral for too long and can’t get your vehicle into the next gear, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop the vehicle and start over.
questions.answerB: Return to neutral, release the clutch, increase your speed, and try again.
questions.answerC: Skip over your intended gear and move into the next gear.
questions.answerD: Just keep the vehicle in neutral.
questions.explanation: If you stay in neutral for too long while double clutching and have difficulty switching your vehicle into the next gear, don't force it. Return to neutral, release the clutch, increase the engine speed to match road speed, and try again.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, you should:
questions.answerB: Check the load and securing devices after driving for no more than 50 miles.
questions.answerC: Not use your mirrors to look behind your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Keep a cell phone in your hand, in case of an emergency.
questions.explanation: Cargo and its securing devices must be inspected before starting a trip. After beginning a trip, the driver should check the load and securing devices within the first 50 miles on the road, every three hours or 150 miles traveled, and after every break.

questions.question: If a vehicle is found to be over-length during a pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Trim the length of the load.
questions.answerC: Ensure flags and lights indicating the oversize load are fastened securely.
questions.explanation: If a pre-trip inspection reveals a load to be oversize, the driver must confirm that all required signs, flags, lamps, and reflectors are safely and properly mounted, and that and all required permits are in their possession.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerA: Always comes as a result of physical distraction, not mental distraction.
questions.answerB: Can be elevated by pre-programming radio stations.
questions.answerC: Can be avoided by eating while driving.
questions.answerD: Can be avoided by not engaging in complex conversations while driving.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of distraction, do not engage in complex or emotionally intense conversations while driving. Pre-programming radio stations before your trip and avoiding eating, drinking, or smoking while at the wheel can also help you avoid becoming distracted while driving. Remember that mental distractions that take your attention away from the task of driving can be just as dangerous as physical distractions.

questions.question: A header board is used to:
questions.answerA: Allow a driver to see behind them.
questions.answerB: Protect the driver from moving cargo.
questions.answerD: Prevent the driver from leaving the tractor.
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect drivers from moving cargo in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a crime that would disqualify an applicant from a hazardous materials endorsement?
questions.explanation: There are a number of crimes that will disqualify a person from receiving a hazardous materials endorsement for seven years. Among these offenses are arson, robbery, and crimes of dishonesty, fraud, or misrepresentation. More serious crimes, such as murder, result in a lifetime disqualification.

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: Controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: Controls how quickly air leaves the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Controls the temperature of the air entering the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Controls the temperature of the air leaving the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: Failing to drain the tanks in an air brake system can result in:
questions.answerA: Water freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do this can cause damage. For example, water that has built up in the system could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: In cold weather, an alcohol evaporator should be checked and filled:
questions.explanation: An alcohol evaporator can help prevent ice from building up in an air brake system. In cold weather, the evaporator should be checked and refilled every day.

questions.question: If the brake pads rub against the brake drums and create too much heat:
questions.answerB: The brakes will become extra sensitive.
questions.answerD: The air compressor will kick on to cool the brakes.
questions.explanation: Brakes heat up with use. If they are overused and become too hot, expansion and chemical changes will make them less effective and eventually cause them to stop working altogether. This is known as "brake fade."

questions.question: Where can you find the tire load rating?
questions.answerA: On the inside of the driver’s door
questions.answerC: On the side of each tire
questions.explanation: A tire load rating is the maximum safe weight that can be carried by a tire at a specified pressure. This number is stated on the side of each tire.

questions.question: What can happen if your vehicle has a high center of gravity?
questions.answerB: It may be difficult for you to see the road.
questions.answerD: The tires may not be able to handle the weight.
questions.explanation: The height of a vehicle's center of gravity is very important. A high center of gravity (cargo piled up high or heavy cargo on the top of a load) increases the possibility of your vehicle tipping over.

questions.question: What is Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW)?
questions.answerA: The total weight of a vehicle and its cargo
questions.answerB: The total weight of a vehicle before cargo
questions.answerD: The maximum weight allowed to be transported by a vehicle
questions.explanation: Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW) is the total weight of a single vehicle and its load of cargo.

questions.question: When turning quickly to avoid an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply your brakes as you steer.
questions.answerB: Give yourself extra clearance by turning more than needed to miss the object.
questions.answerC: Turn just enough to miss the object and avoid turning more.
questions.answerD: Steer and accelerate at the same time.
questions.explanation: When turning quickly to avoid an object, turn only as much as is necessary to clear it. Do not apply the brakes while turning.

questions.question: To confirm that a trailer has ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Look under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look under the hood for the ABS sticker.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure if a trailer is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Check traffic thoroughly in all directions.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Keep your vehicle in its lane.
questions.answerD: Steadily use the brakes throughout the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you should thoroughly check traffic in all directions. Before entering the curve, reduce your speed sufficiently so that further braking or shifting is not required. Keep your vehicle in its lane and continue checking traffic in all directions.

questions.question: Areas of the road that are shaded:
questions.answerB: Usually do not contain moisture, so they can’t freeze.
questions.answerC: Will remain slick after ice on other areas of the road has melted.
questions.explanation: Because they are exposed to less sunlight, shaded patches of road will stay cooler longer than other areas of the road. Due to the lack of direct sunlight, shady areas can remain icy and slippery after ice on other areas of the road has melted.

questions.question: If pulled off to the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Allow your taillights to alert other motorists.
questions.answerB: Turn on your emergency flashers to warn other motorists.
questions.answerC: Keep your lights off to avoid distracting other motorists.
questions.answerD: Keep your door open to warn other motorists.
questions.explanation: If you must stop and park on the side of the road, make sure to turn on your emergency flashers. This is especially important at night. Taillights are not an adequate when alerting other drivers because the drivers may mistakenly think your vehicle is moving normally and collide with it.

questions.question: On trucks and buses, where are ABS malfunction lamps located?
questions.answerC: On the outside of the vehicle by the passenger’s door
questions.explanation: Tractors, trucks, and buses with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps located on their instrument panels. Trailers have yellow ABS malfunction lamps on their left side, either on the front or rear corner.

questions.question: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test:
questions.answerA: Applicants will not have to identify the ABS.
questions.answerB: Windshield wipers are not to be addressed.
questions.answerC: Shock absorbers only need to be checked on one axle.
questions.answerD: The steering box should be checked for leaks.
questions.explanation: During the external inspection portion of the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you must verify that the steering box is securely mounted and not leaking.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection portion of the skills test, an applicant will be required to:
questions.answerA: Explain to the examiner what should be checked and why.
questions.answerB: Let the examiner check the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Talk to a mechanic to prove their knowledge.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection skills test, you will need to explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: When checking tire condition during the vehicle inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the insides of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the outsides of the tires are more worn than the insides of the tires.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the middles of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the tires have even wear.
questions.explanation: When examining your tires during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that treads are evenly worn.

questions.question: When using your mirrors, you should frequently look at your tires to:
questions.answerB: See if the tires are rolling properly.
questions.answerC: See if the tread is sufficient.
questions.answerD: Get a sense of the size of the tire in relation to other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Check your tires regularly when looking in your mirrors. This helps ensure that you will notice a tire fire, if one should happen. Tire fires may occur when a tire is under-inflated, if dual tires are touching, or if the tires are otherwise overheated.

questions.question: To stop in a vehicle that uses air brakes, the driver should:
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in a vehicle with air brakes, push the brake pedal down. The harder the pedal is pressed, the more air pressure is released.

questions.question: When starting the vehicle during the pre-trip inspection, the coolant temperature should:
questions.explanation: After starting your vehicle during the pre-trip inspection, you should watch the gauges. The coolant temperature should gradually rise to a normal operating range.

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be helpful to see a wider area.
questions.answerD: Are illegal to be used in most states.
questions.explanation: Many large vehicles have curved, convex mirrors. Convex mirrors allow drivers to see a wider area than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: What do anti-lock brakes do?
questions.answerA: Help a driver avoid wheel lockup
questions.answerC: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling uphill
questions.answerD: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling downhill
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent the vehicle's wheels from locking up from hard brake application.

questions.question: Poor weight balance:
questions.answerB: Makes handling a vehicle more difficult.
questions.answerC: Increases a driver’s ability to steer.
questions.answerD: Makes a vehicle easier to stop.
questions.explanation: If the weight of a load is poorly balanced, it can lead to difficult and unsafe handling of a vehicle.

questions.question: A driver should stop after a short distance after changing a tire to:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the wheel nuts are tight on the newly-changed tire.
questions.answerB: Ensure that there is still enough air pressure in the tire.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the correct tire was changed.
questions.answerD: Ensure that changing one tire did not damage another tire.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, you should stop after a short distance to re-check the tightness of the wheel nuts.

questions.question: When taking the on-road test, you will be evaluated on regular traffic checks. You should not:
questions.answerC: Avoid checking your mirrors near intersections.
questions.explanation: While taking the on-road driving skills test, check for traffic and use your mirrors regularly, especially when encountering intersections. Scan and check for pedestrians in areas where they may be present.

questions.question: The service brake system:
questions.answerA: Applies and releases the brakes when you press the brake pedal while driving normally.
questions.answerB: Applies and releases the parking brakes.
questions.answerC: Applies and releases the emergency brake.
questions.answerD: Applies and releases the axle brake.
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system. The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when you use the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: While driving, if it is discovered a vehicle's ABS is not working, the driver should:
questions.answerD: Use their parking brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working, the vehicle's basic braking functions are still intact. The driver should continue to drive and brake in a normal fashion.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to get out of their way.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, the most important thing to do is try to get out of their way. Avoid making eye contact with the driver and do not let yourself be provoked by gestures. Do not try to challenge aggressive drivers by speeding up.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerA: Usually have low centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: Usually have high centers of gravity.
questions.answerC: Usually are not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Dry bulk tanks require special care when being driven because they have high centers of gravity. Drivers should also be careful because the materials being carried can easily shift in transit, causing a change in the vehicle's handling.

questions.question: To correct a drive-wheel braking skid, a driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Remove your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Turn quickly in the direction of the skid.
questions.answerC: Countersteer after the vehicle is back on course.
questions.explanation: To correct a drive-wheel braking skid, you should first remove your foot from the brake pedal to allow the locked wheels to begin rolling again. Quickly steer in the direction you want to go, then countersteer to prevent your vehicle from skidding in the opposite direction.

questions.question: If transporting 30 feet of cargo on a flatbed trailer, you should use a minimum of ____ to restrain the cargo.
questions.explanation: When transporting cargo on a flatbed trailer, you should use at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Any cargo, no matter how small, should be restrained by a minimum of two tie-downs.

questions.question: When you need to brake, how can you warn drivers behind you?
questions.answerA: Tap on the brakes a couple of times.
questions.answerB: Stick your arm out the window.
questions.explanation: To warn drivers behind you that you are about to slow down, it may be a good idea to first lightly tap your brake pedal a few times to make the brake lights flash.

questions.question: When turning, when should the turn signal be canceled?
questions.explanation: Always signal continuously through a turn. Do not cancel a signal until the turn is finished.

questions.question: The application pressure gauge:
questions.answerA: Shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shows the temperature of air being used in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Shows the pressure of the air coming from the compressor.
questions.answerD: Shows the number of times the brakes have been used.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. Not all vehicles with an air brake system have this gauge.

questions.question: Leaking shock absorbers:
questions.answerC: Will prevent the turn signals from working.
questions.answerD: Pose no threat if the vehicle is only driven on highways.
questions.explanation: The suspension system keeps a vehicle's axles in place. Damaged suspension parts, such as leaking shock absorbers, may be potentially dangerous defects on a vehicle.

questions.question: Roads are most slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerC: The gravel gets washed to the middle of the lane.
questions.answerD: Some tires are not designed for rain.
questions.explanation: Roads are particularly slippery when it first begins to rain. The water mixes with oil drippings on the road that have not yet washed away, creating a slippery and dangerous mixture.

questions.question: When checking the engine compartment:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should not be engaged.
questions.answerD: The gearshift should be in first gear.
questions.explanation: Before inspecting the engine compartment, make sure that the parking brakes are on and/or the wheels are chocked. Check the engine compartment before entering the cab and starting the engine.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a crime that would disqualify an applicant from a hazardous materials endorsement?
questions.explanation: There are a number of crimes that will disqualify a person from receiving a hazardous materials endorsement for seven years. Among these are kidnapping or hostage taking, smuggling, and immigration violations. More serious crimes, such as murder, will result in a lifetime disqualification.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but keep the wheels rolling.
questions.answerC: Fully apply the brakes, let the wheels lock up, and hold the brake pedal down, keeping the wheels locked until the vehicle stops.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, then the process is repeated.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. This makes the road look as if it is merely wet.

questions.question: What is the best way to stop if your brakes fail while you are driving downhill?
questions.answerB: Let the vehicle slow down on its own.
questions.answerC: Let rumble strips slow your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, you will need to quickly find something outside that can stop your vehicle. An escape ramp is the best option. If no escape ramp is available, use the least hazardous available option, such as driving into an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation, you must inform your employer ____ of the violation.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, you should:
questions.answerB: Check the load and securing devices after driving for no more than 50 miles.
questions.answerC: Not use your mirrors to look behind your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Keep a cell phone in your hand, in case of an emergency.
questions.explanation: Cargo and its securing devices must be inspected before starting a trip. After beginning a trip, the driver should check the load and securing devices within the first 50 miles on the road, every three hours or 150 miles traveled, and after every break.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a vehicle inspection report?
questions.answerA: It tells the motor carrier about problems that may need to be fixed.
questions.answerB: It ensures that the vehicle is inspected regularly.
questions.answerC: It keeps drivers accountable for inspecting their vehicles.
questions.answerD: It provides a plan for the next five trips.
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection report allows a driver to inform the motor carrier of issues that could affect the safe operation of a vehicle. If required, the driver should fill out a vehicle inspection report after every day of driving. They should make note of any issues that could affect the safety of the vehicle or that could lead to a mechanical breakdown.

questions.question: When parked on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear flashing lights.
questions.answerB: Use one set of turn signals.
questions.explanation: Always turn on your four-way emergency flashers if you must park on the side of the road. This is especially important when traveling at night.

questions.question: When the brake pedal is pushed down, air brakes work:
questions.answerD: Only if it is warm outside.
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work.

questions.question: Service brakes should:
questions.answerB: Only be tested by a trained mechanic.
questions.explanation: Before driving, you should always verify that your service brakes are in good working order. Testing the brakes before a trip allows you to locate any problems before you need to brake while on the road.

questions.question: How can you avoid becoming drowsy on a trip?
questions.answerA: Get about three hours of sleep beforehand.
questions.answerC: Do not build exercise into your daily routine.
questions.explanation: Strategies to reduce the risk of fatigue while driving include getting seven to eight hours of sleep beforehand; scheduling trips for the hours during which you are normally awake; planning to take breaks during the trip; and exercising regularly.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerA: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: A tank endorsement is:
questions.answerC: Used when transporting both liquids and gases.
questions.explanation: In general, a tank endorsement is required to a drive tank vehicle used to transport liquids or gases. This applies to both hazardous and non-hazardous materials.

questions.question: Alcohol can be removed from your system:
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate, so the only way to sober up after consuming alcohol is to allow your body time to remove the alcohol on its own.

questions.question: Drivers can get traveler information by dialing what number on their phone?
questions.explanation: To access the Florida Department of Transportation's free Traveler Information System, you can dial the number 511 on your phone. The system is updated with information about crashes, commuter travel times, congestion, lane closures, severe weather, construction, and emergency evacuation information on Florida’s interstate highways, toll roads, and other metropolitan roadways.

questions.question: If an emergency vehicle is stopped on the side of a two-lane, two-way road, approaching drivers must:
questions.answerA: Move to the left half of the lane.
questions.answerB: Travel at a speed that is at least 20 mph below the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: In accordance with Florida's Move Over Law, when approaching an emergency vehicle stopped on the side of a two-lane road, you must slow down to a speed that is 20 mph below the posted speed limit.

questions.question: In the event of an engine fire, you should not:
questions.answerA: Turn the engine off as soon as possible.
questions.answerD: Spray from the underside of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: In the event of an engine fire, you should turn off the engine as soon as possible. Do not open the hood if you can avoid it. Shoot foam through the louvers or from the vehicle’s underside.

questions.question: When backing, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Rely only on the passenger’s side mirror.
questions.answerC: Turn toward the passenger’s side whenever possible.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should back up slowly and use the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle. Use a helper to monitor your blind spots whenever possible. You and the helper should agree on a signal for "stop."

questions.question: The suspension system:
questions.answerA: Holds up the vehicle and its load.
questions.answerB: Keeps the load the proper distance behind the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Maintains a safe distance between the vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Lightens the load for the tires.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Damage to a suspension system can be very dangerous.

questions.question: Extremely hot temperatures can cause:
questions.explanation: Because air expands when hot, tire pressure increases as temperatures increase. This can sometimes result in tire failure. Consistently check your tire pressure when making a trip in hot weather.

questions.question: If a traffic light has been green for a long time:
questions.answerA: It will probably stay green as you approach.
questions.answerC: It is likely that the light will soon change to yellow.
questions.answerD: It is likely the light will skip yellow and change from green to red.
questions.explanation: If you are approaching a traffic light that has been green for a long time, there is a good chance that it will turn yellow before you reach it. Start slowing down and be ready to stop.

questions.question: Headlights:
questions.answerA: Are not usually necessary when driving at night.
questions.answerB: Provide better light than the sun.
questions.answerC: Should be on the high beam setting whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Should always be on the high beam setting.
questions.explanation: To improve visibility, you should use high beam headlights at night where it is safe and legal to do so. However, the glare from high beam lights can blind other drivers. You should dim your lights to their low beam setting when driving within 500 feet of an approaching vehicle.

questions.question: The air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, weight should be:
questions.answerC: Placed only on the left side, if possible.
questions.answerD: Placed only on the right side, if possible.
questions.explanation: Weight of cargo should be loaded into a trailer as low as possible. If the weight of cargo is positioned too high in a trailer, it will put the vehicle at risk of tipping over.

questions.question: When double clutching, if you remain in neutral for too long and can’t get your vehicle into the next gear, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop the vehicle and start over.
questions.answerB: Return to neutral, release the clutch, increase your speed, and try again.
questions.answerC: Skip over your intended gear and move into the next gear.
questions.answerD: Just keep the vehicle in neutral.
questions.explanation: If you stay in neutral for too long while double clutching and have difficulty switching your vehicle into the next gear, don't force it. Return to neutral, release the clutch, increase the engine speed to match road speed, and try again.

questions.question: States verify that a CDL or CLP driver has only one such license by:
questions.answerA: Making phone calls to surrounding states.
questions.answerB: Using a computerized system that links all states.
questions.explanation: All U.S. states share information about CDL and CLP licenses in a computerized database. If you apply for a license in one state, a state will check this database to verify that you do not already have one such license in another state.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from the tanks.
